stem: The nurse is monitoring an arterial line. For each clinical situation or waveform description, select whether it represents an Overdamped, Underdamped, or Normal waveform.

rows.text: The waveform has a rapid upstroke and a clearly visible dicrotic notch.
The dicrotic notch is absent, and the systolic peak is slurred or rounded.
The system shows multiple 'ringing' oscillations after a fast-flush test.
There is a large air bubble visible in the pressure tubing.

rationale.correct: Accurate waveform interpretation is critical for dosing vasopressors. (r1) A dicrotic notch (representing aortic valve closure) is a hallmark of a normal arterial wave. (r2) Overdamping 'squashes' the signal, losing the notch and rounding the peak. (r3) Underdamping (overshoot) causes excessive oscillation or 'ringing.' (r4) Air bubbles (soft/compressible) absorb the pressure energy, leading to an overdamped signal.
rationale.incorrect: Underdamped signals usually overestimate the systolic blood pressure; overdamped signals underestimate it.
clinicalPearls: The first action for an overdamped waveform is to check for kinks in the tubing or air bubbles and then perform a fast-flush test.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember: Overdamped is 'Old and Sluggish' (Slurred peak, no notch). Underdamped is 'Upset and Ringing' (Excessive waves).

mnemonic.title: O-A-K
mnemonic.expansion: Overdamped = Air, Kinks, or Sluggish waves.

reviewUnits.heading: Hemodynamic Waveform Analysis
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must troubleshoot pressure transducers regularly. Factors affecting dampening include tubing length, air bubbles, and blood clots in the catheter tip.
